title: Barclays tax bungle: 17,000 customers forced to wait for vital tax documents
text:
276.203 +5.0530 
An administrative change to 'improve efficiency' has created problems for customers of Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) ' Personal Investment Management service 
Some 17,000 Barclays customers are facing delays in accessing vital information they need to declare tax after their money was moved to a different arm of the bank, Telegraph Money can disclose. 
In January Barclays moved the funds of around 17,000 Barclays Personal Investment Management customers across to Barclays Bank Plc a move which was designed to "improve efficiency". 
But the switch has meant some clients have been unable to obtain information they need to work out how much tax they owe HMRC. 
Nick Comfort, a freelance editor from London, said he requested a tax pack on behalf of his son, who has a disability, in April (the start of the current tax year). 
At first he was told there would be a three-week delay. He waited two months and the documents still did not arrive. 
Earlier this week he was informed that Barclays (Swiss: BARC.SW - news ) "could not process the information at present", citing the transfer of portfolios from one division of the banking giant to another. 
Another customer who inquired in January was told he would have to wait until the end of September to find out how much his deceased father's estate is worth. 
A Barclays spokesman said: "The delay is because of the complexity around having two reporting tax packs this year. Formerly, customers would have received their packs in May and June. The focus on ensuring quality and accuracy between a consolidation of the two has also added time to the process. 
"As part of an administration migration in January, Barclays Personal Investment Management customers have experienced some delays with the issuance of their tax packs. We apologise for this and are working hard to resolve the situation as quickly as possible for our customers"
